message_1:
A company has data on the annual income, education level, work experience and age of its employees. Using principal component analysis, determine the percentage of total variance explained by the first two principal components. 

Assume the following are the variances for the first four principal components of the data set: 

- Principal component 1 variance = 105.23
- Principal component 2 variance = 56.78
- Principal component 3 variance = 20.56
- Principal component 4 variance = 12.90
message_2:
To determine the percentage of total variance explained by the first two principal components, we first need to calculate the total variance of all four principal components. Then, we will calculate the combined variance of the first two principal components. Finally, we will find the percentage of the total variance explained by the first two principal components.

1. Calculate the total variance of all four principal components:

Total variance = Principal component 1 variance + Principal component 2 variance + Principal component 3 variance + Principal component 4 variance

Total variance = 105.23 + 56.78 + 20.56 + 12.90
Total variance = 195.47

2. Calculate the combined variance of the first two principal components:

Combined variance of first two components = Principal component 1 variance + Principal component 2 variance
Combined variance of first two components = 105.23 + 56.78
Combined variance of first two components = 162.01

3. Calculate the percentage of total variance explained by the first two principal components:

Percentage of total variance explained = (Combined variance of first two components / Total variance) * 100

Percentage of total variance explained = (162.01 / 195.47) * 100
Percentage of total variance explained â‰ˆ 82.88%

So, the first two principal components explain approximately 82.88% of the total variance in the data set.
